questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with hypertension, sweating, and frequent headaches. Imaging reveals a thyroid nodule, and tests show elevated serum calcitonin. The family history includes similar early-onset cases. What condition is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MEN 2A

 

Explanation: A history of hypertension, sweating, and recurrent headaches in a young male is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The presence of a thyroid nodule with elevated serum calcitonin indicates medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. A positive family history of similar early-onset cases supports the diagnosis of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A).

  • MEN 2A (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2A) is an autosomal dominant syndrome.
  • Occurs due to gain of function mutation of RET proto-oncogene

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a rapidly growing thyroid mass accompanied by severe pain and hoarseness of voice. Imaging shows the direct invasion of surrounding structures, including the trachea and oesophagus. The diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is confirmed. In managing this condition, which of the following is not typically included?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radioactive iodine

 

Explanation: Radioactive Iodine is not typically used for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma due to the lack of iodine uptake in this aggressive form of thyroid cancer.

 

  • Management of Anaplastic carcinoma:
    • Resectable Tumors (restricted to Thyroid): Total thyroidectomy + Central Neck Dissection + Modified Radical Neck Dissection
    • Unresectable Tumors: Palliative care with tracheostomy for airway obstruction
      • Chemotherapy: Doxorubicin (Option C)
      • Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors: Dabrafenib, Trametinib (Option D)
      • Tumour Debulking: Isthmusectomy done if pressure over the Trachea. (Option B)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female recently underwent total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following is not part of her post-surgical management?

choices.text: Immediately start high-dose thyroxine (T4) to prevent hypothyroidism.
Stop thyroxine (T4) for 6 weeks before a whole-body scan.
Administer recombinant TSH if stopping thyroxine (T4) is intolerable.
PET scan if thyroglobulin rises despite normal neck USG and chest X-ray.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Immediately start high-dose thyroxine (T4) to prevent hypothyroidism.

 

Explanation: High-dose thyroxine (T4) is started to prevent proliferation of thyroid tissue (to prevent cancer recurrence).

 

Post-Surgical Management of Thyroid Cancers:

  1. Thyroxine Therapy:
    • High-Risk Patients: Thyroxine is used to suppress TSH to prevent cancer recurrence. TSH was maintained at a lower normal limit.
    • Low-Risk Patients: Thyroxine is given at physiological levels to maintain normal thyroid function.
  2. Radioiodine Therapy:
    • Stop Thyroxine (T4): Discontinue thyroxine for 6 weeks to increase TSH levels (Option B), enhancing iodine uptake. If intolerable, switch to triiodothyronine (T3) for 2 weeks or use recombinant TSH. (Option C)
    • Whole-Body Scan: Performed to detect and ablate any residual thyroid tissue or cancer cells.
    • Radioactive iodine (RAI) has no role in Medullary carcinoma
  3. Imaging and follow-up: Ultrasound Neck and Chest X-ray.
  4. To detect recurrence:
    • Thyroglobulin Levels: Monitored as a marker for cancer recurrence.
    • PET Scan has maximum sensitivity for detecting recurrence and is indicated if thyroglobulin levels rise despite normal ultrasound and chest X-ray (Option D).
    • RAI ablation can be repeated if cancer recurs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goitre. Postoperatively, the patient is monitored for complications. Which of the following is least likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypercalcemia

 

Explanation: Hypercalcemia is not a typical complication following thyroidectomy. Instead, parathyroid insufficiency is more common, which can lead to hypocalcemia (low calcium levels).

 

Complications of Thyroidectomy:

  • Hemorrhage:
    • Bleeding from muscular arteries or slippage of ligature from superior thyroid vessels.
    • Complication: Tension hematoma causing respiratory distress. (Option A)
    • Management: Immediate re-operation, open sutures, control bleeding, drain hematoma, and close the wound.
  • Respiratory Obstruction:
    • Primary Cause: Laryngeal edema from extubation injury. (Most Common Complication)
    • Other Causes: RLN palsy and tension hematoma.
  • Nerve Injury:
    • Commonly Injured Nerve: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
    • Other Injuries: RLN Injury causing palsy (Option C) and cervical sympathetic trunk causing Horner's syndrome. (Option B)
  • Parathyroid Insufficiency:
    • Ligating the inferior thyroid artery away from the thyroid leads to parathyroid vascular infarction.
    • Causes hypocalcemia (low calcium levels) presenting 2–5 days post-surgery.
  • Thyroid Insufficiency: Total thyroidectomy leads to hypothyroidism and requires lifelong levothyroxine replacement.
  • Thyrotoxic Crisis: Inadequate preoperative preparation in hyperthyroid patients, leading to the release of thyroid hormones during surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a thyroid pathology is being considered for the procedure shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

 

Explanation:

  • The Procedure in the given image is Minimally Invasive Video-Assisted Thyroidectomy (MIVAT), and Thyroiditis is contraindicated for this procedure.

 

Minimally Invasive Video-Assisted Thyroidectomy (MIVAT):

  • MIVAT is a surgical technique for thyroidectomy using endoscopic assistance through small incisions.
  • Most common approach is through the axilla (Others: Transoral, retro auricular, Nipples)
  • Indications:
    • Benign Thyroid swelling: Size < 3 cm; typically requires hemithyroidectomy. (Option B)
    • Papillary Carcinoma: Size should be < 2 cm; usually involves total thyroidectomy. (Option C)
  • Contraindications: Thyroiditis
  • Advantages:
    • Cosmetic Benefit: Smaller incisions result in less scarring.
  • Recovery: Generally associated with quicker recovery and less postoperative discomfort than traditional open surgery.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is undergoing a thyroidectomy, and the surgical team uses a specialized retractor to improve exposure and facilitate the operation. Identify the retractor.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Joll’s retractor

 

Explanation: Joll’s retractor is a self-retaining retractor specifically designed for thyroid surgery, providing excellent exposure by effectively retracting the thyroid gland and surrounding structures.


 

Deaver’s Retractor (Option A): A General-purpose retractor used in various abdominal and thoracic surgeries

Richardson Retractor (Option C): Commonly used in abdominal surgery for abdominal wall retraction.


 

Volkmann Retractor (Option D): Often used in orthopaedic surgery, particularly for retracting soft tissues, but not specifically designed for thyroid surgery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including weight loss, palpitations, and tremors. A large thyroid nodule is noted on examination, and laboratory tests reveal elevated thyroid hormones with suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. An ultrasound shows multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Antithyroid drugs followed by total thyroidectomy
Treat with lugol iodine followed by surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Antithyroid drugs followed by total thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: The patient has toxic multinodular goitre, also known as Plummer’s disease, characterized by multiple overactive thyroid nodules causing hyperthyroidism.

It is more common in females and is the second most common cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Toxic multinodular goitre

Also known as Plummer’s disease, characterized by multiple overactive thyroid nodules causing hyperthyroidism.

Epidemiology

More common in females and occurs often after 60 years of age

Second most common cause of hyperthyroidism

More prevalent in Iodine deficient region

Pathophysiology

  • Chronic iodine deficiency or thyroid dysfunction → reduced hormone production → increased hypothalamic TRH secretion → persistent TSH stimulation of the thyroid gland → hyperplasia of thyroid nodules

 

  • Multiple somatic mutations of TSH receptor occur in long-standing goiters (> 60% of cases) → autonomous functioning of nodules (toxic MNG) → hyperthyroidism

Clinical features

  • Painless goiter with multiple palpable nodules
  • Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis

Lab investigations

  • ↑ T3 and ↓ TSH
  • Neck USG - multiple nodules within the thyroid parenchyma
  • Increased radioiodine uptake by multiple hyperfunctioning (hot) nodules
    • Decreased uptake by the rest of the gland
    • Hypofunctioning or cold nodules may also be present in the multinodular gland.

Management
  • Antithyroid drugs followed by Total Thyroidectomy are preferred.
    • Antithyroid drugs (Carbimazole, Methimazole) are to make the patient euthyroid and stabilize the patient before surgery.
    • Total thyroidectomy is to remove the toxic nodules and resolve the underlying problem.
  • Radioactive Iodine Therapy: Add - “(Iodine-131)”
    • Alternative or adjunctive treatment to destroy overactive thyroid tissue, especially useful if surgery is not feasible or desired (Option B)
    • Given in high doses as uptake is less compared to graves. Hence, it is not preferred before surgery.

 


 

Thyroid hormone replacement therapy (Option C) is not used for treating hyperthyroidism; it is used for managing hypothyroidism.


Treatment with lugol iodine followed by surgery (Option D) can lead to the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, where excessive iodine can exacerbate hyperthyroidism, particularly in patients with multinodular goitre. Hence, it is avoided.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis presents with a rapidly growing thyroid mass, dysphagia, dyspnea, and hoarseness. Biopsy confirms diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Which of the following is most appropriate for treating this patient?

choices.text: External beam radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External beam radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy

 

Explanation: The patient has thyroid lymphoma, specifically diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is a rare form of extranodal non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which External Beam Radiotherapy (EBRT) and Chemotherapy (R-CHOP regimen) are the standard treatment approaches

  • Management:
    • First-line Treatment: External Beam Radiotherapy (EBRT) combined with Chemotherapy, R-CHOP regimen which includes:
      • R - Rituximab
      • C - Cyclophosphamide
      • H - Hydroxydaunorubicin (Doxorubicin)
      • O - Oncovin (Vincristine)
      • P - Prednisone
    • In cases of residual or recurrent disease: Surgical intervention (Option A)

 

Expectant Management with Hormone Replacement (Option C) is inappropriate as it addresses symptoms rather than targeting the underlying disease.

 

Chemotherapy followed by Thyroidectomy (Option D) is not the standard approach; surgery is reserved for cases where the disease persists or recurs after initial treatment.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman has recently undergone surgery for papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). Postoperative pathology reports indicate:


	Tumour Size: 3.8 cm

Which of the following scoring systems is specifically used to assess the prognosis in the postoperative setting?

Explanation:

  • The MACIS Scoring System is designed for postoperative use, as it considers the completeness of surgical resection, unlike other scoring systems that are used preoperatively.
  • Used to evaluate the risk of recurrence and survival after initial treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with midline neck swelling, persistent diarrhoea, and elevated serum calcitonin. Imaging shows the tumour confined to the thyroid without lymph node involvement. Histopathology reveals amyloid stroma. Which of the following is most appropriate for managing this condition?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and histopathological examination, showing amyloid-rich stroma and elevated calcitonin, indicate Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma.
  • Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection is appropriate for managing tumors confined to the thyroid.
  • Modified radical neck dissection is indicated if only there is significant lymph node involvement. (Option B ruled out)

 

Management of Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC):

  • MTC is a TSH-independent tumor, so Radioactive Iodine (RAI) therapy is ineffective. (Option A ruled out)
  • Surgical Management:
    • If restricted to the thyroid: Total Thyroidectomy (TT) + Central Neck Dissection (CND).
    • If there is the involvement of Level 6 Nodes or other nodes: Total Thyroidectomy (TT) + Central Neck Dissection (CND) + Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND)
    • If Calcitonin levels >200 pg/mL: Consider Prophylactic Neck Dissection.
  • Radiotherapy: Used primarily for local symptoms.
  • Metastatic MTC: Managed with Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors.
  • Preoperative Considerations: Always rule out pheochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism.

 

Monitoring and Follow-Up:

  • Calcitonin Doubling time (sensitive marker)
  • CEA

 

Radioactive iodine therapy (Option A) is ineffective for medullary thyroid carcinoma as it is TSH-independent.

 

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors and radiotherapy (Option C) are generally used for metastatic cases or symptomatic control, not initial management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old with midline neck swelling and persistent diarrhoea has an enlarged thyroid gland. The family history includes pheochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism. The image shows a histopathological examination of the thyroid. Which marker is most valuable for monitoring this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum Calcitonin

 

Explanation: The clinical scenario with diarrhoea, enlarged thyroid with a family history of pheochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism (MEN 2A syndrome), and HPE showing amyloid-rich stroma points towards Medullary carcinoma of the Thyroid (MTC). 

  • Arises from parafollicular C cells (C cells) in the thyroid, derived from the neural crest.
  • Associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B (RET Mutations).
  • Clinical Features: Midline neck swelling, persistent diarrhea (due to serotonin), and flushing (due to histamine).
  • Metastasis: Lymphatic and hematogenous spread, commonly to the liver.
  • The tumor produces calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and chromogranin A.
  • Serum calcitonin, a critical biomarker secreted by parafollicular cells , is used for diagnosis and monitoring; levels drop after surgery but rise with recurrence.
  • Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is the investigation of choice for diagnosis, characterized by an amyloid-rich stroma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with a midline neck swelling which moves upwards when she swallows. On examination, the swelling is suspected to be related to the thyroid gland. What is the most likely anatomical structure responsible for this movement, and what is the clinical significance of this feature?

choices.text: Prevertebral fascia - distinguishing thyroid masses from parathyroid masses.
Pretracheal fascia - causes thyroid masses to move with swallowing.
Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia - encloses both the thyroid and trachea.
Superficial fascia - supports the thyroid gland’s position in the neck.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Pretracheal fascia causes thyroid masses to move with swallowing

 

Explanation: Pretracheal fascia causes thyroid masses to move with swallowing

  • It encloses the thyroid gland and allows it to move with the trachea during swallowing
  • Berry's ligament also firmly connects the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring the gland moves with the trachea during swallowing.
  • This anatomical relationship is useful in physical examinations to distinguish thyroid masses from other cervical masses.

The prevertebral fascia (Option A) is a part of the deep cervical fascia that covers the prevertebral muscles and surrounds the vertebral column.

It is located posteriorly in the neck, behind the pharynx, esophagus, and trachea.

 

The investing layer of the deep cervical fascia (Option C) surrounds the entire neck and encloses the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. It provides a general covering for the deeper structures but does not explicitly enclose the thyroid gland.

 

Superficial fascia (Option D) is a thin layer of connective tissue beneath the skin containing fat and superficial vessels. It does not enclose the thyroid gland or affect the movement of deeper structures like it.

questions.text: A 32 year old female patient presented with complaints of midline swelling in neck without any palpable lymph nodes. FNAC and biopsy revealed the image below. Which of the following should be the management of this condition ?

choices.text: Thyroidectomy + Removal of enlarged lymph nodes
Thyroidectomy + Removal of enlarged lymph nodes + MRND

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thyroidectomy

 

Explanation:

  • The given scenario is suggestive of Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) without any enlarged lymph nodes, the treatment of choice should be thyroidectomy.
  • If lymph node enlargement or metastasis is present, then total thyroidectomy along with the removal of enlarged group of lymph nodes with or without ipsilateral modified radical neck dissection (MRND) is done. (Option A, B, C)
  • If no lymph node enlargement, or no metastasis is present, then, only thyroidectomy is done.

 

Thyroidectomy

  • Position: Rose position ("barking dog" position).
  • Types:
    • Total - entire gland is removed
    • Near total -a small cuff of thyroid tissue is left behind
    • Subtotal - a large cuff of thyroid tissue is left behind
    • Lobectomy - only one lobe is removed
    • Hemothyroidectomy - one lobe with isthmus is removed
  • Incision: Kocher's transverse cervical collar incision.
  • Sub-platysma Flap Elevation: Raised superiorly to the thyroid cartilage and inferiorly to the suprasternal notch.
  • Exposure: Strap muscles are incised in the midline and retracted laterally to expose the thyroid gland.
  • Nerve and Parathyroid Preservation: Identify and preserve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, superior laryngeal nerve, and parathyroid glands.
  • Gland Mobilization by dividing superior, middle, and inferior thyroid vessels.
  • Resection: Perform total or partial thyroidectomy as indicated.
  • Hemostasis and Closure: Ensure hemostasis, place a drain if necessary, and close the wound in layers.

questions.text: Which type of incision is typically used for thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kocher’s collar incision

 

Explanation:

  • Kocher’s transverse cervical collar incision is made in thyroidectomy.
  • It is a transverse incision made about 2 cm above the clavicles, extending across the front of the neck.
  • This approach provides excellent access to the thyroid gland while minimising visible scarring.

Killian’s incision (Option A): In septoplasty for a deviated septum, a curvilinear incision is made 2-3 mm above the caudal end of the septal cartilage on the concave side.

Gridiron incision (Option B): In appendectomy, Gridiron incision is made perpendicular to the right spinoumbilical line at the McBurney’s point.

Lanz crease incision (Option D) is made centering at McBurney’s point, as shown above. It is also used in appendectomy and is cosmetically better than other incisions.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient with a history of long-standing goiter, presented with complaints of sudden, painless increase in the size of swelling of the neck. Biopsy revealed the presence of follicles suggestive of carcinoma. What is the most common site and route of metastasis in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bones, hematogenous

 

Explanation:

  • The history of long standing goiter, sudden, painless increase in size of swelling, biopsy showing follicles is suggestive of follicular carcinoma, in which the most common site of metastasis is bone, and the route is hematogenous.
  • Lymphatic spread is not seen.
  • Most common sites: Flat bones, Vertebra (Thoracic vertebra)

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with neck swelling and a history of childhood neck irradiation for Hodgkin’s lymphoma. On examination, a hard mass is found in the neck. FNAC confirms thyroid carcinoma with HPE image given below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Papillary thyroid carcinoma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario suggests papillary thyroid carcinoma, which is common in the 3rd to 4th decade and often follows childhood irradiation.
  • Characteristic histological features include:
    • Papillary projections
    • Optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei)
    • Pseudo-inclusion bodies
    • Psammoma bodies (Dystrophic calcification)

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman has a 5 cm thyroid tumour with extrathyroidal extension, cervical lymphadenopathy, and no distant metastasis. Based on the TNM staging system, what is the most accurate classification for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T4 N1 M0

 

Explanation:

T4 indicates extensive extrathyroidal extension, N1 signifies regional lymph node involvement, and M0 denotes no distant metastasis.

 

TNM Staging of Thyroid Carcinoma

 

Category

Description

T (Primary Tumor)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, limited to the thyroid.

Tumor ≤ 1 cm, limited to the thyroid.

Tumor > 1 cm but ≤ 2 cm, limited to the thyroid.

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 4 cm, limited to the thyroid.

T3

Tumor > 4 cm, limited to the thyroid or minimal extrathyroidal extension.
 

Tumor > 4 cm, limited to the thyroid.

Tumor with minimal extrathyroidal extension (e.g., strap muscles).

T4

Tumor of any size with extensive extrathyroidal extension.

T4a

Tumor invades subcutaneous soft tissues, larynx, trachea, oesophagus, or recurrent laryngeal nerve.

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.

N (Regional Lymph Nodes)

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Regional lymph node metastasis.

N1a

Metastasis to level VI or VII lymph nodes (pre-tracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal).

N1b

Metastasis to unilateral, bilateral, or contralateral cervical or superior mediastinal lymph nodes.

M (Distant Metastasis)

M0

No distant metastasis.

M1

Distant metastasis present.

questions.text: All the following forms the boundaries of Beahrs' triangle except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Superior Thyroid Artery

 

Explanation:

The superior thyroid artery does not form the boundary of the Beahr triangle.

 

Beahrs' triangle:

  • Boundaries:
    • Medially: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove.
    • Laterally: The common carotid artery.
    • Superiorly: The inferior thyroid artery.
  • Significance: It helps surgeons avoid injury to critical structures, particularly the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), during thyroid and parathyroid surgeries.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male undergoes a total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goitre. Postoperatively, he experiences hoarseness and difficulty speaking. Which anatomical site is most commonly associated with this nerve injury during thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Berry’s ligament

 

Explanation:

  • One of the most commonly nerve injured during thyroidectomy is the Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), a branch of the vagus nerve. Berry’s ligament is the most common site of RLN injury during thyroidectomy because the nerve is directly associated with this region as it enters the larynx.
  • The RLN provides motor innervation to all intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle, which is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).
  • It controls the vocal cords, playing a crucial role in voice production and airway protection.

The RLN loops around the right subclavian artery, but this is generally not the site of most common RLN injuries during thyroid surgery (Option A)

 

 The left RLN loops under the arch of the aorta before ascending to the larynx. Injury to this nerve can occur with excessive manipulation or dissection around the aortic arch, but it is less common than injury at the level of Berry's ligament (Option B)

questions.text: During thyroid surgery on a patient, significant bleeding occurs near the superior pole of the thyroid gland. Which vessel branches from the artery supplying this region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) External carotid artery

 

Explanation: The superior pole of the thyroid is supplied by the Superior thyroid artery, a branch of the External carotid artery.
